Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: We love: The bristling array of manual controls ....We hate: The time taken to process RAW images....Verdict:An ideal compact substitute for a DSLR The Nikon Coolpix P7000 is being pitched by the imaging giant as the crowning glory of its compact Coolpix range to date, aimed squarely at the dedicated snapper who needs a high spec compact digital camera that still manages to pack many of the settings and options of a full DSLR. Is it a yay or nay from us? Only once you've delved into our Nikon Coolpix P7000 review will you know whether to raise a royal cheer or blow a common raspberry. If you're already a dedicated follower of the Coolpix brand then you'll remember that the predecessor of the Nikon Coolpix P7000 was released about a year ago, and it only takes seconds to realise how many ch ... anges have been made since the P6000. There's some heft to the Nikon Coolpix P7000, but it feels very reassuring Even the basic shape of the Nikon Coolpix P7000 has altered dramatically from its forebear – it's much chunkier and heavier (360g including battery and SD card) and feels reassuringly solid in the hand, despite the front grip having reduced in size. The LCD monitor has noticeably expanded from 2.7″ to 3.00″ and boasts much more detailed images care of the 921,000 dots and a wide viewing angle. The megapixel count on the Nikon Coolpix P7000 has been reduced, however, from 13.5 to a more modest 10.1 but it still makes use of the same large scale 1/1.7-inch image sensor as the P6000. No restraints with the optical zoom, on the other hand, which has increased to a wide-angle 7.1x (the 35mm format equivalent to 28-200mm) and glides smoothly (albeit with a low growl) in operation. Manual settings aplenty on the P7000 The other major transformation in the Nikon Coolpix P7000 is the sheer volume of manual controls which bristle along the top and back like quills on a porcupine. Alongside the usual mode dial (which contains three custom settings and a new Low Noise Night Mode), tiny power button and shutter-with-zoom-ring, the camera now sports an added dedicated manual control dial for fast launching the likes of white balance, ISO and picture quality, plus a large supplementary dial for EV compensation. Somehow Nikon have also managed to squeeze on to the same level a programmable Av/Tv button which perches dangerously close to the edge and is fiddly to locate but is still extremely useful. Check out our Best HD camera Top 5 now One of the new features that can be preset via the Av/Tv button on the Nikon Coolpix P7000 is an electronic Virtual Horizon that's a Godsend when trying to keep your landscapes in perspective. While the new-improved LCD is an undoubted asset when framing up, the option of using the supplied viewfinder in very bright conditions remains – the down side is that because this is an optical rather than electronic system, only 80% of the frame is viewable – maybe this could be addressed next time. The other raw issue with the Nikon Coolpix P7000 is the, er, RAW issue. The P6000 offered RAW images using Nikon's own NRW file types which could then be converted only with their own ViewNX software (which wasn't Mac friendly). The new machine now carries ViewNX 2 which is Mac friendly for the upgraded NRW+ RAW files – three cheers, except each Fine RAW image takes seven seconds to complete so you're unlikely to do much continuous shooting in this mode. The good news is that the Nikon Coolpix P7000 has dispensed with the lame GPS tagging system of its predecessor, reduced the unnecessarily high ISO 6400 setting to 3200 and installed 720p HD movie-making, complete with an external microphone input for stereo recording. Both still and movie picture quality is exceptionally good, even in the high ISO settings using the in-built noise reduction. The top end PowerShot G shooters now have a serious rival. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
The revamped Coolpix line of Nikon compact cameras certainly has the look of quality. With the new Nikon P7000's classic black body and a range of manual dials, it seems on the surface perfect for photographers who know what they're doing and want a little more control over and quality from their digital compact camera.
But with Nikon P7000 prices around £450, are you better off getting another DSLR to serve as your backup camera?
With Nikon well in the ascendency in the DSLR market, the company is attempting to make hay while the sun shines. The Canon G-series has long been the choice of anyone looking for a (almost) pocketable compact to accompany their DSLR, but with Nikon DSLRs stealing more and more of the limelight, the 10.1MP, all-metal Nikon P7000 could be just the ca ... mera to sway Canon users away.
With fancy features thin on the ground – 720p video is all you get – and enough manual controls to keep the most experienced photographers happy, the P7000 makes a huge first impression. But how is it in use?
The Nikon P7000 looks the business. Clad in dull, gunmetal black and following the G12's approach of scattering the toplate with dials and buttons, it is, like its Canon cousin, an intimidating camera at first, particularly if you're not familiar with terminology such as "BKT", "QUAL" or "WB" might mean.
But if you are, the Nikon P7000 is a snap to set up. The menu system is excellent, as is the 3-inch, 921,000-pixel monitor, but you won't have to poke it into action much. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Very good photo quality, with lower-than-average noise levels through ISO 1600; Generally solid body with lots of dials and buttons; 7.1X, 28 - 200 mm zoom lens with image stabilization; Large and very sharp 3-inch LCD display (though it doesn't rotate); Optical viewfinder (a rarity these days); Tons of manual controls; Auto Scene Selector for the point-and-shoot crowd; Hot shoe for external flash; Customizable buttons, dials, and menus; Built-in neutral density filter and electronic level; Active D-Lighting brightens shadows, restores some highlight detail; Records 720p24 video with stereo sound, use of optical zoom; Redeye not a problem; Stereo microphone input, HDMI output; Optional wide-angle conversion lens, wireless remote
Cons: Very sluggish interface means long waits w ... hen entering/exiting menus or playback mode; Quick Menu dial hardly a time-saver; AF system can be unreliable at times; Exposure can be hit-or-miss -- some highlight clipping -- shadow detail lacking with Active D-Lighting off; Long write times in continuous shooting model; Optical viewfinder is small -- flush design means lots of nose smudges on the LCD; Function (Fn) button not terribly useful; Can't access memory card when camera is on tripod -- some plasticky parts on top of camera
The Nikon Coolpix P7000 is a feature-packed camera that produces good quality photos and HD videos. The problem is that you spend too much time waiting, and not enough time taking pictures. In photography, timing is everything, and having to wait for menus to appear can cost you a shot. I would be more forgiving if the P7000 was a $199 camera, but it costs 2.5 times more than that. It's definitely worth looking at, considering all it has to offer, but you should absolutely, positively try one out to see if you can deal with its sluggishness. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
The Nikon Coolpix P7000 is a camera that combines great image quality, extensive manual controls, and a 7.1X optical zoom lens.
When you're behind the lens of the 10-megapixel Nikon Coolpix P7000, you almost feel like you're at the helm of a jet. The camera is peppered with physical buttons, offering fast access to manual settings via a cockpit-like array of controls. DSLR owners will feel right at home behind the wheel of the Coolpix P7000, which offers great image quality to go along with those extensive imaging controls.
Because the Nikon Coolpix P7000 puts all of its manual controls front and center--more so than any other camera in this roundup--it also has the most challenging learning curve. Novices are bound to be a bit intimidated by its array of buttons and dials, ... but photographers who have used Nikon's DSLR cameras will welcome the familiar button layout.
It lacks the flip-and-pivot LCD screen of the Canon PowerShot G12, but in other respects the Nikon Coolpix P7000 is the spitting image of the G12. Both offer a flash-supporting hot shoe, a battery-saving optical viewfinder, an electronic level dubbed the 'Virtual Horizon', a lens with 28mm wide-angle coverage and F2.8 maximum aperture; the Nikon's bulky body is a hair slimmer and lighter than the Canon's.
The Nikon Coolpix P7000 holds an edge in optical oomph over the Canon PowerShot G12: Its 7.1X optical zoom lens gives it the highest zoom range of any camera in this roundup, stretching from 28mm to 200mm. The Coolpix P7000 also has a superior optical viewfinder; the zoom lens never creeps into your wide-angle view, as happens with the G12's optical viewfinder.
The 17 buttons on the Nikon Coolpix P7000 provide some amazingly quick shortcuts to the camera's manual controls. Among them are a one-touch toggle right next to the shutter button for aperture priority and shutter priority, a thumb-operated automatic exposure lock and automatic focus lock button; a custom mode wheel that lets you jump quickly between aperture, shutter, and white-balance bracketing modes, ISO settings, image resolution settings, and on-screen histograms; and a mode dial with three user-defined custom presets. The P7000 takes great photos in Auto mode, but you'll get a lot more out of this camera by diving into its manual settings.
In our subjective testing of a group of five advanced point-and-shoots for image and video quality, the Nikon Coolpix P7000 finished a close second to the PowerShot G12, with an overall performance mark of superior. The images it snapped were the sharpest ones we saw from any camera in the bunch, and its scores for exposure quality and colour accuracy were only a shade behind those of the G12.
On the other hand, if you plan to shoot a lot of video, you'll be better off with a different camera: The Nikon Coolpix P7000 finished next-to-last in our subjective tests for video quality, and its 720p footage (at /24 frames per second) outscored only the standard-definition-shooting Samsung TL500 in our tests. The Nikon camera's battery life is good, with a CIPA rating of 350 shots per charge with the LCD turned on.
Standout features include the unit's excellent macro mode, which lets you get within an inch of your subject and capture an extremely sharp shot with shallow depth of field. In our tests, the Nikon Coolpix P7000 also did the best job of in-camera editing: After snapping a shot, you can choose to have the camera automatically enhance the image via Nikon's Active D Lighting correction, Quick Retouch mode, or skin softening; and you can even apply filters such as a Miniature Mode setting.
Unlike competing cameras, the Nikon Coolpix P7000 applies its filters and editing work to a copy of the original image, rather than overwriting the source photo. As is true of the G12, continuous shooting isn't a strong suit: The P7000 tops out at around 1.3 shots per second at full resolution.
Group test: what's the best compact camera?

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I bought this little baby as a carry along when I don't want to drag my D7000 with battery grip and a bag of lenses around. I like the fact that it has lots of control options including custom white balance, bracketing and the ability to shoot RAW! It's nice to be able to go full manual when you have the time to compose a shot. Picture quality is pretty sweet on this little gem and the macro capability is pretty awesome! The tiny viewfinder is pretty useless, so I always use the screen to compose and shoot. No biggie though, it's a point and shoot! I also got a generic version of the ML-L3 wireless remote for 2 and a half bucks from another site ;). It's great when you want to put it on a tabletop tripod or get in a group photo. I don't shoot much video on this or at all for that mat ... ter, so I can't comment on video quality. I do have a couple of minor gripes. The light meter is so tiny that when in manual mode you can't really see whats going on unless you look very closely and the yellow on white indicator marks don't do well to contrast against each other. Not a deal breaker, but a small annoyance. The aperture range and shutter time are limited. It only stops down to f/8 and the max shutter length is 30 seconds. Again, this is a point and shoot, so these aren't deal breakers. I guess I was just spoiled by my DSLR! Having said that, I carry this thing EVERYWHERE! Even when I have the D7000 with me, this is in the bag as well. All in all, I think you'd be very happy with this camera. Even though it's a couple of years old now, it holds up very well. I'll use this for a long while. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I use the P7000 for scenery and macro shots with and without people. I like the picture control customization features, especially the YGRO filtering system when shooting in B&W. These filters work just like the ones I used to use with film cameras. I never seen any other digital camera have this feature. I usually shoot in aperature priority mode and this camera is perfect for that kind of shooting. The controls are there on the camera; not in a menu system when you want to tweak the exposure. I lock the exposure with my thumb on the AE-L button and lock the focus with my index finger on the shutter release button. It couldn't be easier. Even using the exposure index dial is simple and within easy reach by my thumb. The LCD display is accurate and displays the image large enough for ... you to make decisions about exposure without shooting and enlarging the image first. The popup flash is perfect. You don't have to remember to turn off the flash because it won't operate when you leave the flash in the closed position even when you have the camera set for auto flash. The camera is a perfect size and has a good balance to it. I especially like the right hand thumb pad. On other cameras, my thumb keeps changing settings accidently because there is no place for the thumb to rest or grasp the camera without pushing a button. I do wish the flash could work with the wide-angle adapter attached and that it had more power. Sometimes I need a little fill in the foreground, but I have to use an auxillary flash to get the results I want. I wish the LCD flipped up so the low-angle shots could be seen easier. I shoot a lot of landscapes with an object in the foreground that needs to be in a crucial part of the composition. It is hard to do this without taking a photo first then looking at the shot afterwards. This would also come in handy when I am shooting macro shots of plants and insects that are close to the ground. Over all I think this camera delivers and more what Nikon said it would. The Nikon P7000 is easy to operate right out of the box with a lot of features that you can grow into to expand the full features of the camera. Finally, a point and shoot camera with the features of a DSLR but lightweight. 4 1/2 stars. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I purchased this camera 7 months ago hoping for a mini version of the Nikon D3/D700 in a lightweight, easy to carry body. The camera has got many futures and I use most of them. Menu is very similar to Nikon's DSLR cameras. I love the manual controls as they make it easier to control the camera. The Nikon SB-400 is a must, to take pictures of people, kids without spending time on red-eyes removal. Many Nikon accessories work very well with the camera such as SC-28 flash cable, hotshoe-PC adapter, old Nikon flashes (manual mode) etc. Overall I'm happy with the product, but there are few things you should keep in mind. It's not as robust, dust/weather proof as D3 nor D700. Any bit of dust/sand will cause the lens cover to fail and it will not fully open. The part has to be replaced, as ... blowing compressed air doesn't help. Don't take it to the beach without the underwater casing or other protective casing. The large crisp LCD screen is not calibrated - colors are not as saturated in reality as shown on the screen. Battery doesn't last for long as expected, therefore I strongly recommend the second battery when travelling. Still haven't figured out how to properly set Picture Control settings to my liking and I'm still playing with it. I wished camera had more manual controls. It will never be a Nikon D3/D700 series camera, but for the 1/10th the price you can't go wrong. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Great image quality, with lots of controls. While not as fast or responsive as a DSLR, it performs extremely well for a P&S. Good low light performance, also very quiet operation (no loud click), fun macro capabilities. It has a few peculiarities you need to learn to work with, but well worth the money and time investment. Small size, relatively durable construction. Intuitive design, most-used controls are easily accessible. Shutter lag hasn't been a problem, but time between shots is a bit slow, even in JPG mode. In low light the autofocus has some challenges, but zoom out a bit and find a high-contrast area on a subject and you're golden. Huge bright screen is very nice. All in all great camera, very happy with it.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: The ease of changing exposure, white balance, ISO, etc. Makes this a quick handling little camera. The control it gives you is quickly done. One of the best features is the 921K dot display, the same quality as on the D7000, and it is gorgeous. It is much easier to grip than small digital cameras and the viewfinder, hotshoe, and RAW capability, are great additions to a small camera! But, of course, it's really about the images, and the P7000 gives beautiful images, even when enlarged.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: After recently purchasing a Lumix DMC-LX5 with the LVF-1, I received the P7000 as a gift from a friend. I had been tempted by the Canon G12 and the Nikon P7000, but settled on the LX5 to get the 24mm wide. Now, with the two cameras to compare, I can safely say I like both of them. The P7000's 200mm reach is very handy, and, for me, the camera delivers more accurate color. RAW image quality over the iso range is very good - comparable to the LX5 - with fine, well distributed noise that yields a 35mm slide like result. I did notice some significant heating after taking some test video clips and playing back. The camera got hot enough to get very noisy until it cooled down (about 5 minutes). Operation is still sluggish with the latest firmware. The lens cover hung a bit after I used it in a d ... usty environment, but it recovered itself. Since the latest ACR plugin has lens correction for the P7000, there is essentially no distortion, CA or vignetting post processing. Lens is excellent up to 135 equivalent, very good centrally at 200mm equivalent. The three User modes are a great addition, especially considering how cumbersome it is to make setting changes. For me, U1 is for landscape, U2 is for landscape with autobracketing, U3 is for grabshots. I'm now carrying both compacts in a small case for trail and travel use. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: As a professional photographer I own some great DLSR and lenses, but at times I don't want carry all that with me. After researching, I decided the P7000 was going to be exactly what I wanted. Turned out it is exactly what I wanted! Note: I only researched Nikon, but the Cannon G11 is a similar camera that is supposed to be great also. This camera is great for shooting photos around my home, of my pets, family functions and trips. The flexibility of shooting in automatic, a priority mode or all manual is great. Manual mode is really easy to use, two dials control the aperture and shutter speed, the exposure indicator is helpful along with the histogram. Both are small on the display, but still easy enough to view. ISO, WB and quality are all easily accessible on a dial. The camer ... a handles high ISO and ow light situations very well, much like my DLSRs. The auto white balance does well on indoor lighting. There is no shutter lag, but there is a delay after the photo is taken and the information is being written on the card before you can take another image. I have not used the camera in a situation where this would be an inconvenience, but it may be when shooting a sporting event or such. the focus is very sharp. Macro setting is great. The camera is definitely not small and will fit in your pocket only if you have a large pocket. I love the retro look, multiple dials on the top of the camera to access functions, it is not slim and sleek. The shape doesn't fit the best in my hand, but it may be because I am used to a much larger DLSR. It is an amazing point and shoot. I would definitely recommend it to any one who wants the control of manual exposure and the flexibility of a point and shoot. I have been using it constantly since I received it in the mail. It is just so much fun to have a little camera that functions like my DSLRs! expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Nikon got it right this time
Item.Review: Nikon finally fixed those things people did not like about the P90, P100 and L110. Lens protecting mechanism is a plus. Quality photos with good sharpness and color. Intuitive controls. Separate battery charger allows you to shoot with a backup battery while recharging the original battery. Have not used movie function yet. It is a bit pricey, but I believe it is the best quality point and shoot camera available now.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: This was not a gift. I have been a nikon shooter for many years and wanted to stay with Nikon technology for my point and shoot camera. As it turned out, it is a little more than I expected in a point and shoot camera. I was able to program and use this camera without opening the manual. The menus are very easy to move around in and understand. In fact, the ability to load 3 different mini shooting banks, U1,U2 and U3,into one of the top camera dials is really a nice feature. Having the majority of the controls on the top of the camera like my SLR's makes me feel right at home. I was a little disappointed in the speed it takes to write a raw file to the card, 4 to 5 seconds, but I do not intend to shoot sports with this camera. The color is as good as my expensive SLR's and the stabilizer ... does a great job on hand held subjects. The view finder is a little small but can be used if necessary. The focusing light indicator is also right next to the view finder and can be distracting. The built in Scene Programs all seem to be excellent which is great for my personal use. I will use this as my backup camera when I travel to lighten my load without any hesitation. I did detect motor noise on the audio when shooting video however an external mike took care of the problem. I advise buying a spare battery or two if you are going to do some serious shooting and editing. expand » « collapse
Item.HelpfulCount: 1 out of 1 found this review helpful.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I have had this camera for about 2 weeks now. So far it seems well built and has been pretty user friendly. The battery life isn't that great (good for about 3-4 hours of shooting). I don't like the fact that I am forced to use Nikon software to transfer the pictures onto my computer (or an SD card reader). Also, the top menu dial is great for quick adjustments, but i wish they would also let you select some of those options in the main menu. The HDMI port is not a standard size so an adapter is needed. The video quality is not that great. All and all it takes great pictures and I am very happy with the camera.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Having for a long time looked for an alternative to my heavy D700 for day to day photography, I've found with the P7000 the ideal companion. It allows a huge bunch on settings, to work in expert modes (as on a reflex), and the most important, it fires nearly instantaneously. The image quality at 800 iso is awesome. Even at 1600, it is still possible to make some nice prints. Using the raw files allows to treat the image with a dedicated software for even better results. 3200 iso still gives details, but they are quite unsharp. I particularly appreciate the dedicated ring to set the exposure compensation, with a LED indicating you're not at zero. Very clever from Nikon's engineers. On wide angle position, the lens shows a visible distortion, but the built-in compensation of the camera brins ... it back to zero: impressive. The wide angle position could have been wider (28mm is not enough in some conditions), but the zoom amplitude is comfortable (max. 200mm). Don't expect miracles at this position, but nevertheless, the internal treatment delivers images always sharp, even in bad light conditions. Bad lights is the reason that led me to buy this camera. Taking picture during concerts, even far from the stage is not a problem anymore (if you allow the autofocus to take its time at 200mm, seen the aperture of only 1:5,6). In sunny conditions, however, hight light are easily burnt. Its better to check the histogram and to under-expose. The built-in D lighting will compensate the darkness of dark zones. In these conditions, the optical viewfinder is good to have, despite the fact that it doesn't cover the entire image that will be taken. As said earlier, this expert compact camera is fully configurable to suit the most expert photographer preferences. On the other hand, should you give it to someone who is not familiar with complicated cameras, you may set it on green or even easier, on automatic scene recognition mode and let the Nikon work for you. Start-up time is a little big too long for me, as well as the time it needs between two shots. Nevertheless, this is compensated by the nearly immediate firing (provided that you've focused previously). Video mode allows to zoom when filming, and gives HD movies with a reasonable sound quality. Slightly too big to be kept in your pocket, it is supplied with a shoulder strap. As a conclusion to this review, I could only recommend expert photographers wanting to have a compact camera always with them to buy a P7000, it will always be capable to bring good quality pictures in most of the conditions a photographer could meet. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Big things in a small package
Item.Review: I travel a lot and after 20 years of lugging an SLR and DSLR camera,lenses,filters, etc., I wanted to carry a small but quality camera. This camera produces excellent pictures for such a small camera. There are many features and this is not a camera for a beginner. To get the most out of the P7000, you need to learn all the controls and read the manual. The pictures come out well exposed, to the point that post production adjustments are minor to nil. You have almost complete control over the shot or you could set it to complete automatic. The LCD display is extraordinary. The controls are nicely placed. The build of the camera reflects high quality. What things aren't so great would be the autofocus system can be tempermental. You really have to be in a certain range (it is in the manual) ... to get the green light to take the shot. Sometimes the lens can be slow to go to telephoto legnth, and it can be jerky. The learning curve can be steep unless you are familiar with the Nikon menu system. All in all though it is well worth the price and produces some really great pictures all the way down to macro. Highly recommended! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: P7000 Review First off let me say this, this camera is NOT a replacement for an SLR. For low light situations, or tacking pictures quickly of fast moving subjects there is no substitute for an SLR. That said, this is still am impressive little camera. Pros:??? EV Dial. Having a dedicated dial to adjust the EV settings is very convenient. I have found that the camera tends to make shots alittle to dark for my tastes, so I often shoot at it +.3 to overcome this??? Picture controls. I own a D700 and love how I can fine tune the saturation and hue to make colors pop. This camera will also allow you to do this, and it makes a noticeable improvement.??? The 3 User settings on the main command dial. You can program some very unique settings into the camera and quickly recall them for m ... any situations. ??? The hot shoe is great for mounting on a real flash. This built in flash works well on anything that is close to the camera, but it is very weak in even slightly demanding situations. ??? White Balance. You can program three preset custom white balance cards. I use an Expodisc for my D700, you can use it for this little camera too! (Do not press the disk too hard over the lens or you could damage it) Also you can adjust the white balance manually by degrees Kelvin, just as with a pro SLR.Cons:??? ISO performance. I have to disagree strongly with the cameras proclaimed ability to do very well in low light. Pictures are noticeably noisy starting at ISO 400, so I try to limit it to only 200 or so. ??? Autofocus. In optimum situations it works fine, but when zoomed out it can really start hunting for a lock on. After three or four failed attempts the camera actually will display a reinitializing the lens message, and will retract and redeploy the lens.. You can focus manually, and it displays a magnified image of what you're focusing on in the center to assist you. But it's a cumbersome system.??? Battery Indicator. The camera only tells you the battery power remaining when it's about to die!?! ??? Menu settings. There are certain functions in the camera that are locked out depending on which shooting mode you have the camera set. For example Interval Timer is locked out of the main P,S,A,M priority settings???...why???? WB Balance. Yes I listed the WB as a Pro above, but it also has a negative. Under normal in the house lighting everything is yellow, and I mean VERY yellow. This is easily overcome by fine tuning the white balance, but it's still an extra step that might cause you to miss a good shot. ??? View Finder. The viewfinder is useful for bright sunny days, but it only covers 80% of the frame. What it covers is perfectly centered, but you have to bear that in mind when composing images. ??? Low light function. Turn this on and see for yourself. Very noisy right from the screen! It's a very nice camera if you understand its limitations, anyone who loves fine tuning with settings on their SLR's will love this as a causal take everywhere camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I eagerly awaited this camera as a replacement for my Canon G10. I'm a Nikon fan-boy and was glad to see Nikon in this market segment. Alas, there are several deal breakers that put this camera behind it's chief rival. I bought the camera yesterday from the 9th Ave store and I'm returning it today. There was no floor sample for me to try.I saw a review and forum postings on [@] and didn't believe them. Image quality seems near- or equal-DSLR. I didn't bother with reviewing the images after I realized I don't want a camera with this kind of performance. Here's my experience with the camera, as limited as it is.1) No RAW buffer. The camera locks after a RAW image is captured and does not release until the file is written. Most enthusiasts and pros shoot RAW. Hello, Nikon, I thought you were ... listening to your customers. This is so eight years ago.2) Slow refresh after menu settings. The G10 returns to the image preview instantly after a setting has been changed. The Nikon hesitates before refreshing the screen. Especially annoying after changing ISO or White Balance. The Canon has a ISO dial. At least the Nikon has a dial for exposure compensation.3) Itsy-bitsy dials and buttons. I don't have large hands, but the controls seemed tiny to me, especially compared to the G10. The control wheel on the back of the camera, near the top of the body is too small to move easily, as are the other controls on the top of the body. Nikon is known for it's ergonomics, but who tested this camera?4) The camera got warm. The right thumb rest on the back of the body got warm after only a few minutes of use. Wasting energy here; Nikon claims 350 exposures per charge. I wonder if that's optimistic. And, no replacement battery is available as of this writing.5) Where's the articulated LCD? Canon G11 has one, other Nikon models have them. If you have to use the screen to aim the camera, why not have the convenience one that swings and rotates? 6) Why not a 24mm equivalent? OK, maybe it would have to be only 135mm or 180mm at the long end. I could live with that for a ultra wide. The screw on 20 or 21mm accessory lens is a colossal inconvenience; I had one on a Konica Minolta A2. What are the engineers thinking?7) Still no 100% optical view finder. I HATE holding the camera at arms length to aim it: think camera shake and discrete image-making. Perhaps I speak for my colleagues when I contend we would prefer a true, 100% optical view finder. The ancient Nikon SP range finder film camera had one, the Leica has one. To fix these objections, the camera might have to be larger, but it would be a real photography tool. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I was at first confounded by the menus but I'm growing acustom to them and I am getting to like them. They are no intuitive to me. The camera does lag a bit when switching from preview to shooting mode. I was quite impressed with the flash, small size but lots of power. Battery consumption is very favorable and the picture quality under a variety of conditions I do like. If you are a Nikon shooter like me this camera will take some of your existing flash accessories including the SU800. I'm so pleased I purchased another with the intent to convert to IR.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Fantastic camera in a portable size!
Item.Review: I love this little camera! My day job as a commercial pilot takes me all over and having an almost SLR-like camera in a small package is huge to me. Packing this along instead of my SLRs is cake. The image quality, build, and abilities of the camera are wonderful. From full manual control to a worthy zoom it is basically everything I wanted in a compact. My previous 'travel' camera was the Sigma DP1 (phenomenal sensor/image quality), which is great in its own right but the P7000 goes a step further in overall usefulness. I wanted something with a faster start up time, good zoom and better auto-focusing for playing outside. The P7000 has all this and then some. In fact, my last trip to the Philippines I brought this along instead of one my SLRs. I wasn't disappointed! Only compl ... aint I can muster is the viewfinder, but the LCD does a good job so it was a matter of adjustment really. While definitely not a replacement for my SLRs, it is a great little camera to have along at all times. Highly recommended! expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: -I bought the camera having experience with Canon's PowerShot G3. I wanted to have a smaller point-and-shoot camera, but one that had additional functions that I could use with ease. -The use of several knobs rather than one or two menus makes this camera, in my opinion, very easy to use. The most commonly used functions are within one or two button or knob manipulations. -The size of the LCD screen is great, but I'm also used to the PowerShot's smaller screen. Screen resolution is good too. It would be nice to turn off display of certain functions that mean little to me, but I'm not aware of any camera that is able to do that. -On a trip to the mountains, the large screen and lens capability allowed me to quickly take large area shots that appeal to me. It also did great on a few clo ... se-ups, although I haven't fully explored its capabilities at close range. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I wanted a camera easier to carry than a DSLR without giving up the ability to shoot RAW or getting the reduced features of most point & shoots. The P7000 came with a solid set of controls and makes a nice companion to my DSLR. Some of the most useful settings are accessed or set with buttons and wheels on the camera body making them easier to set without having to burrow into multi layered menus. The body size is easy to hold but not hard to carry. I would not call it a pocket camera and I carry mine in a small case on my belt. Image quality is good. Images at ISO800 are very nice. With the VR on and slow sync flash I shot a number of hand held street scenes at night that came out very well. I've shot up 3200 and noise picks up quite a bit depending on the lighting. Focus ... is good though on occasion it doesn't lock onto something I think it ought to. Moving the frame slightly takes care of it. JPEGs are good. In less than ideal light, colors come out a bit better shooting RAW. I also wanted a view finder for the times when the sun is bright enough to make the LCD hard to see. The LCD turned out to be better than I was used to from point and shoots and in a week at Disney I used the view finder once or twice. It's just a basic view finder without focus or shot information displayed. I updated the firmware to version 1.1 which made a noticeable improvement in RAW write time and the lag in the LCD updating as the Quick Menu dial is rotated. With the firmware updated the RAW write time was a fraction of a second behind my D7000. The RAW files are an NRW format not NEF. If you're a CaptureNX 2 or ViewNX 2 user it's not a problem. ViewNX 2 comes free and will convert to a TIFF or JPEG if your using something else. For me the P7000 is easy to carry when I don't want the bulk of a DSLR and with enough controls and features I can still do something creative along the way. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great controls in a compact package
Item.Review: I'm using this to teach my grandson photography. It can operate in point-and-shoot mode for now. As his experience grows, he will be able to control aperture, shutter speed and focus. I'm pleased with the control over ISO, white balance and exposure compensation not found on other cameras. I really appreciate the optical finder. I find it frustrating when you can't see the typical camera's LCD in bright light.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I chose the Nikon P7000 to supplement my DSLR. I've been using it for about a week. I wanted a camera that was less conspicuous, more portable, had a long zoom, good macro capabilities, allowed easy manual, and produced quality images control. So far it meets all my expectations. The Lowepro case recommended by B&H for this model is a bit small to include anything in addition to the camera (like a spare battery).

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: The learning curve is a bit steep and only similar to my Nikon professional products. This is a great camera for the pro to carry for none professional use, (vacations and such) where lugging the gear is not practical or necessary. Results are good when shooting in the automatic mode, but somewhat cumbersome when controlling shutter speed and F stops. The camera is slow to react between viewing a photo and shooting again. Start-up from off is faster. There is a shooting lag time that I cannot get used to after spending so much time with my D2-H and D-300s. The camera needs the wide angle attachment to satisfy even moderate wide shots. But, that's another expense and it takes time to mount the extra lens. The Macro feature works very well. The HD video is a plus and the microphone input wor ... ks with my professional mics. The Auto focus in video mode does not work well when zooming. It's better to setup the shot, focus and then shoot. All in all the P7000 is a giant step up from most point and shoots, but too much of a compromise for those who are use to Pro gear. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great Vacation and Walk Around Camera
Item.Review: Small, excellent photo quality, good lens, and more features than most similar cameras. Battery life is very good. One battery supports a day of fairly intense shooting. I bought a second battery as a backup, but never needed it. Charged the used battery overnight and was ready for another day of shooting. Also purchased the 32Gb memory card, which will record at store 1600 RAW with JPEG images. In camera JPEG processing is good, and allows photos to be emailed to friends and family during trip. You will need a large hard drive for your PC when you return home for image storage and archiving.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: A fine camera to take when you don't have the time or hands to carry anything more. I use it for kids parties and places where a full-sized SLR would just look out of place. Snapshot territory. Lots of customizable features like a SLR, but only wish it was a little quicker. Need to get camera set up before you shoot. Making on the fly adjustments take some time since many tunings are menu driven. But it has all the basics on handy dials, so changing the exposure, shooting settings and even the major camera functions such as WB can be done quickly. Also, has an amazing view screen. Eyepiece a little on the useless side. Even though it's only (a relative term) 10MP, it has a better quality sensor, so your photos will look excellent with great contrast and color definition. I had a P90 an ... d I must admit the images and color definition were garbage compared to the P7000. On the negative, it's just a little slow, which should be expected. Get a fast SD card and that should help a little bit. Definitely a fun solid-feeling point and shoot camera for when you want to take good quality photos without all the bulk. It's like a P&S for the pro. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: The Nikon P7000 is a sophisticated camera capable of many functions that the average point and shoot person will never use. At the same time, it functions well as the point and shoot that it is advertised to be. Overall, one of the best features of this camera is that it follows closely the controls and functions of Nikon's better DSLR's. To illustrate, I bought the P7000 to supplement my D300 (w/ Nikkor 18-200mm VR lens) on an international study tour I am leading this summer. I wanted a point and shoot to carry on occasions when lugging the D300 around would be overkill -- e.g., informal pictures in cafes, restaurants, on the tour bus etc. At the same time, I didn't want a cheapie pocket camera. The P7000 is perfect. It functions in ways reminiscent of my D300 (and before that my D50). T ... his makes it easier to use -- I don't have to learn different routines. Another reason I chose the P7000 is because it has a rangefinder. Some may say it is pointless (pun intended) in a day with bright, high definition LCD screens. A fixed rangefinder takes us back to Kodak Brownie camera days, doesn't it? (Oops... I just dated myself! :) Anyway, I like the rangefinder because it provides a practical way of framing shots in low light or in settings where the the subject is rapidly moving. Use the rangefinder to point, then shoot. Result?... a high quality digital image. Imagine that! One thing the P7000 is not is a pocket camera. So, give up the idea of a thin profile, carry-it-around-in-your-shirt-pocket type of camera. If that is what you want, consider one of Nikon's S series cameras. Even though I recognized this, I still hoped to carry it easily without using the supplied neck strap emblazoned with Coolpix in yellow letters. So, I ordered the fitted P7000 Horizontal Leather Case (Mfr. # 9817). You won't find a lot of information about this case ??? what it does and does not do. Let me recommend you consider it anyway. It does not have a separate strap, but makes use of the neck strap supplied with the camera. When used like this, it becomes a kind of eveready case, except it is not attached to the camera. What I like about this case (and would have had one sewn on if it had not had it) is the belt loop. The camera is light enough to carry on a man's belt without causing problems -- i.e., weighing down your trousers. (For those of you with shrinking or non-existent glutes, this is an important consideration! :)) The only thing that should have be included, but isn't, is a wrist strap for the P7000. So, I will be getting one, for sure. Imagine pulling the camera out of the case and forgetting it is not attached to anything. You could find yourself waving goodbye to your P7000 camera as it sails over the edge of a cliff or drops into the water from the deck of a ferry. This camera needs a wrist strap. Nikon missed an opportunity to do something creative as well as practical here. I have no hesitation recommending the Nikon P7000, especially to those DSLR users who would like a quality backup or supplemental camera for special trips, family gatherings when the SLR would be overkill, and other such occasions as may arise when you don't want to lug around the heavy duty equipment. I give it 5 stars because it does what it is supposed to do well. Just make sure that this is the kind of point and shoot you want. If you really want a pocket camera, then don't set yourself up for frustration; look at the Nikon S models. But if you want an easy to use versatile camera that you can use to adjust as well as make images, then the P7000 is the top of the P series line in Nikon. You can't go wrong. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Top of it's class picture quality
Item.Review: Been shooting Nikon DSLR's for years. I know how to process Raw images and the value of using RAW. This is the only compact camera I've found that produces a good RAW file. If you are a DSLR shooter and you need a compact pocket camera, this is your camera. You'll see some discussion as to whether or not it is a pocket camera, but as a photographer you should have bigger pockets than the normal person. For a photographer, this is a pocket camera. What it isn't is fast. With firmware 1.1 your processing times on RAW are about 3-4 seconds. A huge improvement over 1.0, but still a bit slow for any action shooting. AF is slow relative to a DSLR, but again you have to look at it's price point and what you are comparing it to. It does have tons of features and all adjustments are easy to ... get to and make if you are used to DSLR menus. The built in flash is usefull for close shots, but the SB-400 is probably a useful accessory. White balance is good and you have the ability to use custom white balance just like the big boys and in my opinion it is an under utilized feature among shooter. It's an easy camera to handhold and get the shot at low shutter speeds. Lots of choices for metering, not so many for Auto Focus, but again.... Although NX2 is an additional cost, if you don't have it, it is worth buying. If you learn to use it, you will be rewarded in the quality of images you can produce. It is a slow program and benefits from being loaded to a RAMDISK or SSD even on a machine that handles Photoshop easily. VIEWNX 2.2 is a huge improvement over the previous versions of View and is FREE. Download it and you won't be sorry. Actually, lots of adjustments even to RAW files can be done in View and done well. You may wish to try View first and then decide if you need the plethera of adjustments NX2 affords over View. Shutter delay is not great, but not bad in manual settings. Of course it isn't bad relative to the price point. Zoom could be longer, but it would cause a trade off in image quality. In reality for my purposes I wish it would go wider and not longer. I find myself backing up in to walls a lot. I used this as a replacement for a LUMIX GF-1 with 4 lenses and EVF and have been thrilled. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: A versatile carry-around camera for the person who wants the option of automatic photography AND the option of complete picture control. With terms and functions familiar to Nikon DSLR users, this camera is for the user desiring high image quality in RAW and/or JPEG format. Dials and buttons allow most setting changes without accessing menus. An extensive Set Up menu allows functional customization and video access is quick and fool proof. The opportunity to download and study the camera manual from the Nikon Website allows a potential purchaser to become aware of the extensive features of this unit. The size and weight of the camera limits pocketability to larger pockets! I would recommend this to a friend who is interested in producing excellent pictures and is willing to spend ... some time learning the many features of the camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Nikon P7000 Fantastic Low Light Photos
Item.Review: I reach for this camera to take photos in challenging lighting situations like school basements, snow sports and church events. The photos are tack sharp and do not require computer processing. The choice of control over the camera settings will please any DSLR photographer. The camera size is larger than expected but still fits in my jacket pocket.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Good in Low Light; Large Clear LCD; Short Lag Time; Good Image Stabilization; Good Image Quality; Small / Compact
Good small camera to carry. Great optics and photo results. Auto focus is a challenge in Macro mode. The lens cover began only partially opening, as has been the case for others.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great P&S...Nikon finally got it right!
Item.Review: The P7000 is a great, great camera. Small and easy to use, it still packs in all the features you'd want in a DSLR without the weight and hassle of carrying around a big system. I often use it in tandem with my DSLR while climbing, as it fits in a pocket and has a huge range with the 28-300mm lens. And, it shoots pretty nice video, too. My only complaints are fairly minor ones: 1. the menus and options seem to run a bit slow, especially the delete image option. 2. Would be nice to have the option to add an external mic for better audio on videos.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD; Great Zoom; Easy To Use; Good Image Quality; Fast/accurate auto-focus; Good Image Stabilization
Cons: LCD does not articulate
Bought to replace my P5100 which was underwhelming to say the least. I looked at the G series Canons, but this Nikon is much more capable. The LCD does not articulate like the G-12, but it is a full 3 inches and has better resolution. Video is not something I am vitally interested in, but when I tried it, I was floored by its quality. Remember, this is not a DSLR (nor is it a camcorder), so don't expect it to produce what a full-frame DSLR will. It has full manual controls and is now my backup to my D3's and D700 at photoshoots. I normally keep it in my glove box of my car as I scan about, looking for that fabled female model str ... eaker. I recommend getting a small, light tripod, or even a monopod if you get more serious about shooting. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Exactly what I needed it for.
Item.Review: I ordered this camera to take as a casual alternate to my d300s. It's lightweight, works incredibly smoothly and takes minimal use to work out any bells and whistles that come with this kind of Point and shoot. Video also looks great. Having a viewfinder is also very nice since I don't typically enjoy using the screen to frame my shots with. Using at parties and walking around make for an enjoyable experience. Due to the size it's clearly meant to be carried around on a shoulder strap, but in a pinch, you can cram it into a back pocket on a pair of jeans as well.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: A very Nice Point and Shoot Camera
Item.Review: It is a sturdily built little camera and has a view finder! Yay! You can actually photograph in the bright sun and see what you are doing. The photos are sharp, there is no appreciable shutter lag, the zoom works well and the controls are located in convenient spots for easy access. Many of the most used functions are available via the buttons and dials so you don't have to go into the menus all that often. I must say that with all of the features and video capability it is a complex piece of equipment but if you don't want the complexity you can just set the dial to program mode and shoot away. The camera has a hot shoe and is capable of using an external flash rather than the built in pop up flash. I have not as yet used the video capability so I can't comment on that. I bought the cam ... era as a backup to my DSLR and to use when I didn't have the DSLR handy or didn't want to lug it with me. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: This camera is very nicely designed, with all of the controls of a DSLR readily available on knobs or buttons instead of buried in menus. Anyone familiar with the layout of a Nikon DSLR will find themselves very much at home. Picture quality is excellent for a small format camera and it has decent low-light performance. However, the autofocus is slow and not very accurate compared to a DSLR. I typically use the mode where I can set the focus point manually. Compared to the DSLRs I've used (D90, D200, D7000) the P7000 autofocus is very frustrating. The pipper will turn green (indicating that what's under it is in focus), only to have it turn out on closer inspection that this is not the case. It is a great pleasure to go back to the D7000 and have the autofocus lock quickly and accur ... ately every time. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I wanted something that was smaller and lighter than my Nikon DSLR but still took great photos. I bought a Canon S90, but it never felt right. The buttons were in the wrong place, my fingers couldn't find a natural handhold, and I missed having a viewfinder. The P7000 felt right from the minute I picked it up. It does well in auto and also gives me all the flexibility to shoot manually. The controls make intuitive sense. Plus I love the longer zoom. The colors also need less adjusting in post processing. I'm very pleased with my purchase.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Produces great quality, and pocket size
Item.Review: I have only owned a Nikon CoolPix P7000 for about a month. But I am very content so far with its performance. I wanted a camera that I could always bring with me where ever I go. Small enough to fit into a pocket, but with high enough quality of lens and image recording to be able to work with the results. The P7000 has not disappointed me yet. I find the buttons and dials very functional. I particularly like the separate 'wheel' which one can change either the shutter speed or aperture setting, depending on the choice one makes. My only critisism is that it seems a little slow in recovery, between shots when set to the Raw image recording. But it may be that I'm too impatient to wait even a short time!

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Just starting our usage on the P7000
Item.Review: My wife and I were looking for a digital rangefinder to augment our Nikon DSLR, primarily for travel. Liking Nikons we were glad to finally find the P7000. We are still getting used to it and it seems to have the full complement of features and in some way the settings are more accessible than the DSLR. The 10 megs give good resolution. I like having the one click access to ISO and white balance settings. The one thing I don't like is not being about to see my f-stop, metering or shutter speed settings through the rangefinder. Having to move in and out to see the screen is cumbersome. The shutter seems to have a little lag to it. But overall, we like the heft and operation

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I got the P7000 as a carry everywhere when I could carry my DSLR. It has all the features and controls of a pro DSLR in a compact size. Image quality is excellent.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I am very happy with the P7000. It is a solid performer. It has excellent auto white balance and takes great photos and video. It is also well built. The Canon G12 may have it beat in a couple of areas (performance of writing RAW and general speed of of using the menu system) but the P7000 is close behind. The P7000 has a larger zoom range and it shoots Nikon RAW so I can use Nikon tools (for me, that was important, may not matter for others). I think Nikon got this one right and got it on par (but not surpassing) with competitors.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I have a Nikon D80 from before and was looking for a camera who was smaler and easy to use in the city and when I travel. This camera satisfying me almost complete. I miss a better protection for the lens. But else this is a perfect camera, takes great pictures with good colors and they are really sharp. I like the HD filming function where you can zoom and also record sound. It has a lot of control-weels so it is easy to use. So it has Only one problem: no good protection for the lens. But that is the same for all these cameras.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I am a Nikon D300 user and bought this camera to carry around in my pocket. I have taken 250 pictures, from handheld Chicago skyline at night to indoor hockey games of my grandson and am very pleased with the picture quality. It is very compact and user friendly with a lot of flexibility. Dials make settings easy and the menus are self explanatory. The zoom works smoothly and takes clear shots even in digital mode. The viewfinder does take some time to adjust to ambient light setting and it is nice to have the optical viewfinder. It's no DSLR for action photos but isn't meant to be and the action scene mode provides reasonable results. Highly recommend.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: This is to replace a Lumix point and shoot because it does not have a viewfinder. Although the Lumix is still functional bright sunlight prevents seeing what you are focusing on. I have a D80 and the similarity of the P7000 and the D80 functions make this a great addition. The viewfinder allows composition when the sun is too bright and the screen on the back comfortably large for easy viewing. It is, of course, bulkier than the Lumix but not so that it won't fit in a jacket pocket.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: There are several things about this camera, that if I'd know about before I purchased it, I would not have bought it. 1. The buttons and dials on the back of the camera are very touchy. One light brush with your finger and you are off to the races going places you did not intend to. 2. The auto focus does not always work, forcing manual focus use. 3. There is no way to review a shot without pressing a button to bring the shot on to the LCD screen. On most cameras you get to review the shot automatically without having to press an additional button. If you take 100s of photos in a day this process gets old fast. 4. This camera has a very wide angle lens. Beware the wide angle when taking portraits or other photos that suffer from the distortion of the wide angle. The camera take high ... quality images and it feels great in your hand, but the issues I mentioned above are beginning to make me sorry I bought this camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I bought the P7000 to carry on business/pleasure trips when it would be inconvenient to lug my full DSLR camera bag. The features are extensive and the User-defined modes allow me to preset things like bracketing for HDR shots in advance. The LCD is very bright and clear and the controls are well-placed and reasonably intuitive. I do recommend spending a few hours with the manual. Oh, and don't forget to upgrade the firmware when you first get one.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Lots of buttons and lots of menus but not intuitive. Quirky: I'd raise the flash in A or program mode but it would not fire regardless of the flash mode selected. I thought it was defective. Checked the manual. Turns out that the continuous setting has to be set to single for the flash to work. Studying the manual is required regardless of how many digital Nikons you have. The 3 HD LCD is great - the same as on my D90. Good battery life, but do get a spare. I like the best shot feature, but it takes some menu surfing to find it. You can take up to 10 continuous photos and the camera will select the sharpest. Perfect for dim museums and cathedrals. The camera also has considerable non-destructive editing capabilities and an HDR feature. You will spend an unusual amunt of time in ... the menus (it does have a green setting). expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Currently use Nikon DSLR system and was looking for something small and with unlimited creative abilities. Thats when I came across the CoolPix P7000. Its a powerhouse, every feature is included, every film speed, every flash setting. You have complete control over this camera. Flash output, slow sync, rear curtain, features that only pros would use. Image quality is excellent, even in low light situaitons. The camera is a bit bigger than one of those little digital cameras. Does not fit in your pants pocket, but does fit in a small bag or coat pocket. Comes with a Nikon strap. The point is, if you are looking for a simple point and shoot with poor image quality this is not the camera for you. If you are in search for a semi pro camera with a suberb image quality and don't feel like luggi ... ng around a large DSLR system, then look no longer, P7000 is fantastic. Read the reviews and more inportantly read the very thick manual. It also shoots RAW format, very nice indeed. 10/10 Nikon really did good job on this little camera.... expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: THE Nikon of point & shoot cameras.
Item.Review:
Pros: 720P Video; Focus and zoom in video; 7X Optical Zoom
I've been searching for a high end point and shoot for an upcoming European adventure. I hadn't purchased a digital camera since October 2000. I began my search looking at the G12 and the S95, both from Canon. Fine cameras and very highly regarded. Its my intention to use this camera to shoot video as well as stills. 720p obviously isn't the highest video resolution available, but certainly is good enough for my purposes. Here's a couple of things that tipped the scales in favor of the P7000. 1. 7x optical zoom. 2. Full zoom and focus in the video mode. Most cameras in this range have fixed focus and zoom in video mode.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I had this camera for a week. It is having high quality images but somehow very slow either on shutter action and on saving the raw images. Hand touches and feeling are all good. The lens moves fast and quite. The image quality is very impressive. Low light performance is also pretty impressive. Video function is very convenient especially allows me to zoom while taking the video clips and the video quality is very good. First day my good 16GB Panasonic SD card was damaged after inserted in. Formatting went OK but after taking a few pictures it reported card access failure and after that I can not use that card anywhere - indicating the error message and won't access the card anymore. It also lock up itself a few times that I had to pull out battery to reboot it. I also had a difficult t ... ime to quickly capture images like I used to. Had to return it. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great option for a compact camera.
Item.Review: GOOD: image quality; shooting functions; operation; LCD; size; zoom range; speedlight compatibility. BAD: viewfinder; no long exposition with high ISO; body heating.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great camera, just a tad big
Item.Review: Great little camera for when I don't feel like lugging my D700 (with battery grip and f/2.8 lenses) around. The menus are a little hard to figure out how to navigate, and setting options isn't always intuitive, but it's a great little camera with great image quality and good low-light capabilities. It would be nice if it were a big smaller so it'd fit more comfortably in a jacket pocket, but that would probably sacrifice more important things. The lag in between shots is a bit long (but I'm also shooting fine-quality RAW files, so that probably slows things down). Much better, especially in low light, than the P5000 this camera is replacing for me.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Bought the camera for an upcoming vacation. Wanted a camera small enough to carry but still give great results. Will use for outside sports shots. The idea of a good 200 mm lens on a compact camera was a strong selling point. Also used for some inside sporting events - have gotten acceptable results with 800-1600 ISO and not extending over 100mm. The range finder is very handy for the bright light or shooting burst mode. Have used digitals from compacts to DSLRs. Find this best for me. This remind me of my 50's vintage Contax.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: Having been a Canon SLR shooter for 20+ years I took a brief rather painful foray into the digital SLR world circa 2005 I was very unimpressed with the images I took and the colors were terrible and I sorta sold all my equip and walked away in disgust fast forward 5 years and I hear a review of these new pro level digital compacts that gave you manual controls, and outstanding images. After a little bit of research I chose the Nikon P7000, and I must say I have been a VERY happy little shutter bug since then. First of all the build quailty on this camera at this price is superb, the retro-style reminds me so much of the range-finders of the 70's and 80's then lets get to the 3.0 view screen WOW! One of the things I couldn't tolerate on my old Canon was the murky unreadable screen, P7000' ... s is a champ! and you will need that bright screen for the manual focus, yes manual focus on a compact, add that to the manual shutter and apeture controls and it's like my old F1 lives again. Now onto the inner workings, this thing allows SO MUCH in-camera processing of images it boggles the mind. You really are in complete control of this camera its a miracle. What has really blown me away is the low light hand held capabilities of this thing I never in my life have been able to get the number of usable low light images hand held as I have in the last couple of weeks. The control dials are all very intuative and easy to use, and the little pop-up flash does a really good job within 5 to 6 ft of the subject. Now are there things I'd like to see? sure exposure info in the viewfinder would be nice, push to select on the thumb wheel too. Since every review MUST have a con, I suppose if this thing lacks anywhere it is in low light in program mode where the AF tends to hunt and hunt for focus and also wants a wider angle aspect to obtain focus your not getting any epic tight shots even with the flash (but with this many pixels you can crop) All in all a top-notch 5 Star effort from Nikon that delivers crisp rich images with all the bells and whistles AND manual control you could ever ask for in a compact. They may have finally brought me back to photography and gained a new lietime customer to boot expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I'm a photojournalist who shoots with all Nikon DSLR gear and had been waiting for a decent compact to carry with me at all times. Because I shoot RAW and use an NEF-Centric workflow (with Photo Mechanic and Capture NX2) I didn't want to get the Canon G series and have to create a different workflow. Already I got a couple of cover-worthy shots that I wouldn't have because I had it in my vest pocket while my big gear was packed away. It's important to download the newest Firmware (v 7.1) which greatly increases the RAW processing time. Otherwise, it's agonizingly slow. The lens, LCD monitor and build quality are excellent, and I have all the control I need. Yes, there is some occasional hang-up with auto-focus, and the optical view finder is not ideal, but if you're a Nikon shooter l ... ike me, you'll find this to be a great addition to your camera bag. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Pretty Good for a P&S- Thank you Nikon!
Item.Review: Note: My review assumes you are familiar with shooting RAW (or at least what it is) and are looking for a camera with advanced features. This camera is LONG overdue. I have been waiting for an advanced Nikon P&S for many years now, something that I could have with me most of the time. A few years ago I got tired of waiting and being disappointed by the Nikon offerings that were supposedly competing in this niche of the market. Completely frustrated, I broke down and bought a Canon G9. It has served me well but was always a source of frustration when I needed supplemental lighting. You see, although I did break down and purchase a Canon camera, I refused to buy a Canon speedlight for this camera, the only Canon product I own, when I own several SB-900s and SB-600s that I use for locati ... on work. Finally, when one day (without warning) I was asked to just take a few pictures at an event my wife was attending, I just got fed up with my inability to shoot with an off-camera speedlight. Still refusing to invest in more gear for my only Canon camera, I decided to try the P7000. I find the operation of this camera to be very similar to my G9. The P7000 is slightly taller and a few controls are slightly different, but no big learning curve here. For me, most of the changes are INSIDE the camera. I will focus primarily on those features from here on out. -I find the menu much more intuitive. While lacking some of the options I was hoping for (Copyright notices you can have added to the metadata, CLS support......after all, isn't this supposed to be a pro's P&S?), I do find it much easier to use than the G9's which still feels like it is written in a foreign language. -Low-light ASA/ISO is much better than the G9. I am finding noise levels at ISO 3200 to be about the same as what you would get at ISO 800 on the G9. Now, this is to be expected as the P7000 is a few generations newer. However, if you are a D3 series shooter, the P7000's ISO 3200 will seem very noisy. -Not sure how big of a problem this will be for most P7000 shooters but it does have a new RAW format. Instead of the .NEF format we all know, Nikon has this camera using an .NRW format. If you keep up-to-date on all of your software, you will be fine. However, older software will not even recognize the file extension. -RAW files are slow to write. Nikon has used a big enough buffer that it does not lock up the camera (anyone remember awful the 5400 was?) but you often get the please wait for image to record message if you try to preview right after exposure. All-in-all, I like it better than my G9, which I also liked. The P7000 has better image quality and is more compatible with my Nikon accessories. It falls short of what I am used to from my FX bodies and I doubt it is quite as good as the G12, but is now my new carrying around camera. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Great little camera,but not that little!
Item.Review: This is not a point and shoot camera even though you can use it that way. I feel like I am using a mini-dslr. A mode dial, compensation dial, ISO, WB and bracket settings are at your fingertips without having to get into a lot of menus. I have used this camera for general purpose and family photos and find it to be fun to use. You can even attach the SB800 to it, although it looks a little top heavy. The SB400 looks like it was made for the camera to me as far as size. I had purchased the Panasonic LX-5, which is a very nice camera, but found it too small for me. The P7000 fits me well and seems well built. I have gotten some very nice photos even in low light. Just don't expect to put in in your shirt pocket. A coat pocket or maybe cargo pants pocket would work pretty well. I recommend th ... is camera for a nice walk around camera without the hassle of a lot of weight. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: Just what I've been waiting for!
Item.Review: I was so excited when Nikon announced the P7000 that after playing with it at the recent PDN show in NYC, I bought one a couple of days later. I had been looking at the Canon G12 and if Nikon hadn't released the P7000, I might have gone with the Canon. The main difference is that the Canon has a movable viewing screen which, while convenient for some shooting situations, was not important enough for me to be a deal breaker. Besides, I'd been using Nikon since the late 70's, I was happy to be able to stay in the Nikon family. I have 3 primary uses for this camera ... travel, every day grab shots, and as a back-up camera when I'm on a job shooting candids and groups. It's built well and feels substantial and comfortable in your hands. It has an ED glass lens with a decent zoom range (7x ... ), impressive picture quality, RAW capture, a ton of adjustments - most of which are accessible without going into the on-screen menu. In macro mode, you can focus down to about 3 inches from your subject. In a pinch I've used it to record video. The video quality is pretty good and the external mic input helps you capture really clean audio. Audio level control is automatic and does a decent job. One other thing that impressed me is it's ability to capture clean images at high ISO. I've shot candids with it at 1600 and the pictures look great. I have no problem recommending this camera to a friend, colleague, or anyone else. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I am a great fan of Nikon DSLRs, starting with a D1 that I purchased in December of 1999. But I have been constantly disappointed by their compact point-and-shoots. The P7000 is no exception. 1) The auto white balance produces unappealing results under compact flourescents. Whereas a Canon SD800 produces flawless colors under the exact same conditions. 2) Despite the dial with ISO on the P7000, it takes so long for the ISO selection to appear on the screen that it is confusing and frustrating. 3) The review time is 2 seconds or nothing. It cannot be lengthened. Whereas, on the Canon G12, SD800 and likely most of the Canon point-and-shoots, the review time can be adjusted, and, even better, the just-taken image will remain on the monitor as long as you keep the shutter button held dow ... n after a shot. 4) The self timer cannot be set to more than 10 seconds, whereas the Canon G12 can be set for anything from 2 to 30 seconds. I find that I often cannot get into a photo within 10 seconds. I am sad that Nikon missed on these features. I would have had liked to have a compact camera compatible with my existing Nikon flashes, but I am returning the P7000. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review: I use this camera as my carry everywhere pocket camera. I regularly donate my services as photographer to volunteer groups involved in outdoor recreation and or conservation. This camera is great for the purpose intended. The options are vast and thus the learning curve is steep. The dials controlling the various functions are easy to use and well placed. One has to practice enough to memorize their function. Many of my photographs are candid portraits in the field and the record feature is a huge bonus. No more juggling camera, notebook, tools, etc in the wind. I push the button and record the subject's information. So what's the beef? I found out in the field (too late to return the camera) the lens cover was not fully retracting. That is a huge flaw! not being to turn on the camera a ... nd start shooting. Gripe number 2:the User's Manual or, Manual del usuario, the language doesn't make a difference, same kid probably translated both Spanish or English equally perplexing, the Spanish reads better. I read the Manual at bedtime-puts me right to sleep. expand » « collapse

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.Review:
Pros: Large Clear LCD; Good in Low Light; Small / Compact
Cons: Lag / Shutter Delay
Great low light images! Easier to carry than DSLR. NRW RAW format is not readable by Adobe software. It must be edited with Nikon software (supplied w/camera). Hopefully, Adobe will develop this capacity for their Camera RAW suite.

Item.Item: Nikon Coolpix P7000 10.1 MP Digital Camera (Black)
Item.ReviewTitle: what pros want in a point & shoot
Item.Review: Great camera for the serious amateur or pro looking for a versatile camera when not wanting to lug your DSLR around.
